Title: Sleep stage classification with ECG and respiratory effort
Authors: Fonseca P, Long X, Radha M, Haakma R, Aarts RM, Rolink J.

Title: What Factors Contribute to Headache-Related Disability in Teens?
Authors: Kemper KJ, Heyer G, Pakalnis A, Binkley PF.
Citation: Pediatr Neurol. 2016 Mar;56:48-54. doi: 10.1016/j.pediatrneurol.2015.10.024. Epub 2015 Dec 24.

Title: The research of sleep staging based on single-lead electrocardiogram and deep neural network
Authors: Wei R, Zhang X, Wang J, Dang X.
Citation: Biomed Eng Lett. 2017 Aug 1;8(1):87-93. doi: 10.1007/s13534-017-0044-1. eCollection 2018 Feb.
Data: RR intervals extracted from the ECG (MIT/BIH Polysomnographic Database)
Performance: Accuracy of 77% and a Cohen’s kappa coefficient of about 0.56
Conclusion: We believe that a continuous improvement of this method, can enable continuous and unobtrusive sleep monitoring at home. This can open up great opportunities for research and take sleep research out of the sleep labs to provide important param- eters for the natural screening of conditions such as obstructive sleep apnea syndrome. We also believe that this research has great prospects in the development of moni- toring for sleep and respiratory diseases.

Title: Obstructive sleep apnoea detection using convolutional neural network based deep learning framework
Authors: Dey D, Chaudhuri S, Munshi S.
Citation: Biomed Eng Lett. 2017 Dec 14;8(1):95-100. doi: 10.1007/s13534-017-0055-y. eCollection 2018 Feb.
Performance: Accuracy 98.91%, Sensitivity 97.82%, Specificity 99.20%
Conclusion: The software for the algorithm reported here can be a good contender to constitute a module that can be integrated with a portable medical diagnostic system

Title: Multiclass classification of obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea based on a convolutional neural network from a single-lead electrocardiogram
Authors: Urtnasan E, Park JU, Lee KJ.
Data: Single-lead ECG acquired using an Embla N7000 amplifier system at the Sleep Center of Samsung Medical Center
Study Population: 86 subjects with length of approximately 6 h and segmented into 10 s durations
Task: Multiclass classification of obstructive sleep apnea and hypopnea
Performance: Mean F1-score of 87.0 for the test dataset
Conclusion: The proposed deep learning architecture achieved a high performance for multiclass classification of OSAH using single-lead ECG recordings.

Title: Deep learning in the cross-time frequency domain for sleep staging from a single-lead electrocardiogram
Authors: Li Q, Li Q, Liu C, Shashikumar SP, Nemati S, Clifford GD.
Data: Single-lead ECG from MIT-BIH Polysomnographic Database (SLPDB), the PhysioNet/Computing in Cardiology Challenge 2018 database (CinC2018) and the Sleep Heart Health Study (SHHS) database
Study Population: A total of 2829 epochs were selected in SLPDB, 261 946 epochs in CinC2018tDB, and 400 547 epochs in SHHSv1 database
Model: CNN. A measure of cardiorespiratory coupling (CRC) was extracted by calculating the coherence and cross-spectrogram of the EDR and HRV signal in 5 min windows. CNN on CRC. SVM to combine the output of CNN with the other features
Performance: An accuracy of 75.4% and a Cohen’s kappa coefficient of 0.54 on the out of sample validation data in the classification of Wake, REM, NREM light and deep sleep in SLPDB
Conclusion: The proposed ECG-based sleep stage classification approach that represents the highest reported results on non-electroencephalographic data and uses datasets over ten times larger than those in previous studies. By using a state-of-the-art QRS detector and deep learning model, the system does not require human annotation and can therefore be scaled for mass analysis

Title: A Novel CNN-Based Framework for Classification of Signal Quality and Sleep Position from a Capacitive ECG Measurement
Authors: Kido K, Tamura T, Ono N, Altaf-Ul-Amin MD, Sekine M, Kanaya S, Huang M.
Task: Classification of signal quality and sleep position
Performance: 0.99 averaged precision and a 0.99 averaged recall
Conclusion: This study could serve to explore the cECG for unconstrained heart monitoring

Title: A deep learning-based decision support system for diagnosis of OSAS using PTT signals
Authors: Arslan Tuncer S, Akılotu B, Toraman S.
Citation: Med Hypotheses. 2019 Jun;127:15-22. doi: 10.1016/j.mehy.2019.03.026. Epub 2019 Mar 27.

Title: A review of automated sleep stage scoring based on physiological signals for the new millennia
Authors: Faust O, Razaghi H, Barika R, Ciaccio EJ, Acharya UR.
Citation: Comput Methods Programs Biomed. 2019 Jul;176:81-91. doi: 10.1016/j.cmpb.2019.04.032. Epub 2019 May 2.

Title: A RR interval based automated apnea detection approach using residual network
Authors: Wang L, Lin Y, Wang J.
Citation: Comput Methods Programs Biomed. 2019 Jul;176:93-104. doi: 10.1016/j.cmpb.2019.05.002. Epub 2019 May 8.
Data: RR intervals extracted from the ECG (PhysioNet Apnea-ECG Database)
Performance: 94.4% accuracy, 93.0% sensitivity and 94.9% specificity
Conclusion: We develop a deep residual network to detect apnea on low-sample-rate RR intervals. The result suggests a possibility of representing RR intervals by neural network. The model showed strong adaptivity when using EDR input.

Title: Deep learning approaches for automatic detection of sleep apnea events from an electrocardiogram
Authors: Erdenebayar U, Kim YJ, Park JU, Joo EY, Lee KJ.
Citation: Comput Methods Programs Biomed. 2019 Oct;180:105001. doi: 10.1016/j.cmpb.2019.105001. Epub 2019 Jul 30.
Performance: Accuracy of the best-performing model was 99.0%
Conclusion: The designed deep learning approaches performed better than those developed and tested in previous studies in terms of detecting SA events, and they could distinguish between apnea and hypopnea events using an ECG signal. The deep learning approaches such as 1D CNN and GRU can be helpful tools to automatically detect SA in sleep apnea screening and related studies.

Title: Sleep apnea detection from a single-lead ECG signal with automatic feature-extraction through a modified LeNet-5 convolutional neural network
Authors: Wang T, Lu C, Shen G, Hong F.
Citation: PeerJ. 2019 Sep 20;7:e7731. doi: 10.7717/peerj.7731. eCollection 2019.
Data: Single-lead ECG (PhysioNet Apnea-ECG Database and UCD Database)
Performance: Specificity of 90.3%, sensitivity of 83.1%, accuracy of 87.6% and AUC of 0.950 per-minute segment
Conclusion: Our experimental results show that our proposed method is useful for SA detection, and achieves better or comparable results when compared with traditional machine learning methods.

Title: Sleep staging from electrocardiography and respiration with deep learning

Citation: Sleep. 2020 Jul 13;43(7):zsz306. doi: 10.1093/sleep/zsz306.
Study Population: 7208 unique patients from Massachusetts General Hospital from 2009 to 2016
Performance:
5 Stages
ECG, Cohen’s kappa=0.476 (±0.040), Macro F1 score=0.545 (0.538–0.552)
ECG + CHEST, Cohen’s kappa=0.514 (±0.040), Macro F1 score=0.575 (0.566–0.582)
Conclusion: ECG and respiratory effort provide substantial information about sleep stages in a large heterogeneous population

Title: Recognition of Patient Groups with Sleep Related Disorders using Bio-signal Processing and Deep Learning
Authors: Jarchi D, Andreu-Perez J, Kiani M, Vysata O, Kuchynka J, Prochazka A, Sanei S.
Study Population: A set of 76 patients including healthy subjects (33) and patients with OSA only (25)
Performance: Mean accuracy of 72% and weighted F1 score of 0.57
Conclusion: A DNN architecture that yields competitive and promising results by using and integrating multimodal data was also presented.

Title: A deep learning-based algorithm for detection of cortical arousal during sleep

Citation: Sleep. 2020 Dec 14;43(12):zsaa120. doi: 10.1093/sleep/zsaa120.
Performance: pr-auc 0.62, roc-auc 0.93
Conclusion: The end-to-end deep learning approach with a single-lead ECG has the potential to be used to accurately detect arousals in home sleep tests

Authors: Chang HY, Yeh CY, Lee CT, Lin CC.
Performance: 87.9% accuracy, 92.0% specificity, and 81.1% sensitivity for per-minute apnea detection
Conclusion: The proposed model improves the accuracy of sleep apnea detection in comparison with several feature-engineering-based and feature-learning-based approaches

Title: Deep learning for automated sleep staging using instantaneous heart rate
Authors: Sridhar N, Shoeb A, Stephens P, Kharbouch A, Shimol DB, Burkart J, Ghoreyshi A, Myers L.
Citation: NPJ Digit Med. 2020 Aug 20;3:106. doi: 10.1038/s41746-020-0291-x. eCollection 2020.
Data: Instantaneous heart rate (IHR) extracted from the ECG
Study Population: Sleep Heart Health Study (SHHS) and Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA)
Performance: 0.77 accuracy and 0.66 kappa of the SHHS for classifying every 30s of sleep into four classes
Conclusion: We demonstrate that the stages predicted by our algorithm can reproduce previous clinical studies correlating sleep stages with comorbidities such as sleep apnea and hypertension as well as demographics such as age and gender

Title: ECG-Derived Heart Rate Variability Interpolation and 1-D Convolutional Neural Networks for Detecting Sleep Apnea
Authors: Sharan RV, Berkovsky S, Xiong H, Coiera E.
Citation: Annu Int Conf IEEE Eng Med Biol Soc. 2020 Jul;2020:637-640. doi: 10.1109/EMBC44109.2020.9175998.
Journal/Book: Annu Int Conf IEEE Eng Med Biol Soc
Data: RR intervals extracted from the ECG (PhysioNet Apnea-ECG Database)
Performance: Accuracy of 88.23% (AUC=0.9453)
Conclusion: The performance of the proposed technique is evaluated against previously used time domain features, frequency domain features, a combined feature set, and logistic regression model (LRM) and SVM classifiers. The proposed method is seen to outperform these baseline methods in detecting apnea and non-apnea segments.

Authors: Urtnasan E, Park JU, Joo EY, Lee KJ.

Conclusion: The results showed the possibility of automatically identifying SA severity based on a short-term normal ECG signal.

Title: Transfer learning from ECG to PPG for improved sleep staging from wrist-worn wearables
Authors: Li Q, Li Q, Cakmak AS, Da Poian G, Bliwise D, Vaccarino V, Shah AJ, Clifford GD.
Citation: Physiol Meas. 2021 Mar 24:10.1088/1361-6579/abf1b0. doi: 10.1088/1361-6579/abf1b0. Online ahead of print.
Data: From single lead ECG to PPG, cross-spectrogram of ECG-derived respiration and instantaneous beat intervals, heart rate variability metrics, spectral characteristics, and signal qualitymeasures
Study Population: Source: 5793 subjects in Sleep Heart Health Study (SHHS); target: 105 subjects in the ‘EmoryTwin Study Follow-up’ (ETSF) database
Performance: Four-class classification was Accuracy (Acc) =68.62% and Kappa= 0.44. Transfer learning showed higher accuracy (1–9 percentage points) and Cohen’s Kappa (0.01–0.13) than those without transfer learning for
Conclusion: Transfer learning approach improves estimates ofsleep state.

Title: Automatic Detection of Obstructive Sleep Apnea Events Using a Deep CNN-LSTM Model
Authors: Zhang J, Tang Z, Gao J, Lin L, Liu Z, Wu H, Liu F, Yao R.
Citation: Comput Intell Neurosci. 2021 Mar 22;2021:5594733. doi: 10.1155/2021/5594733. eCollection 2021.
Performance: Cohen’s kappa coefficient of 0.92, a sensitivity of 96.1%, a specificity of 96.2%, and an accuracy of 96.1%
Conclusion: The results prove that our approach could be a useful tool for detecting OSA on the basis of a single-lead ECG.

Title: SCNN: Scalogram-based convolutional neural network to detect obstructive sleep apnea using single-lead electrocardiogram signals
Authors: Mashrur FR, Islam MS, Saha DK, Islam SMR, Moni MA.
Citation: Comput Biol Med. 2021 Jul;134:104532. doi: 10.1016/j.compbiomed.2021.104532. Epub 2021 May 29.
Data: Single-lead ECG (PhysioNet Apnea-ECG Database and UCD Database)
Performance:
Apnea-ECG: Accuracy of 94.30%, sensitivity 94.30%, specificity 94.51%, and F1-score 95.85% in per-minute classification.
UCD: Accuracy of 81.86%, sensitivity 71.62%, specificity 86.05%, and F1-score 69.63% for UCDDB dataset.
Conclusion: The experimental results outperform the existing OSA detection approaches using ECG signals.

Title: Obstructive sleep apnea prediction from electrocardiogram scalograms and spectrograms using convolutional neural networks
Authors: Nasifoglu H, Erogul O.
Data: Single-lead ECG (combined ECG records from two publicly available datasets HomePap and ABC)
Model: CNN on scalograms and spectrograms from ECG
Performance: The prediction using scalograms immediately30 s before potential OSA onsets gave the best performance with 82.30% accuracy, 83.22% sensitivity. The prediction using spectrograms also achieved up to 80.13% accuracy and 81.99% sensitivity on prediction.
Conclusion: Time-frequencydeep features ofscalograms and spectrograms of ECG segments prior to OSA events provided reliable information about the possible events in the future.

Title: Automatic sleep staging by cardiorespiratory signals: a systematic review

Title: Ensemble of Deep Learning Models for Sleep Apnea Detection: An Experimental Study
Authors: Mukherjee D, Dhar K, Schwenker F, Sarkar R.
Performance: 85.58% accuracy
Conclusion: Deep learning models are compatible to be aggregated as the final ensemble method is able to surpass the best among three models

Title: A deep transfer learning approach for wearable sleep stage classification with photoplethysmography
Authors: Radha M, Fonseca P, Moreau A, Ross M, Cerny A, Anderer P, Long X, Aarts RM.
Study Population: Source: 292 participants, 584 recordings with ECG; target: 60 healthy participants, 101 recordings with PPG
Performance: Four-class classification Cohen’s kappa of 0.65 ± 0.11, accuracy of 76.36 ± 7.57%
Conclusion: The work demonstrates the merit of transfer learning in developing reliable methods for new sensor technologies by reusing similar, older non-wearable data sets.

Title: AI-Enabled Algorithm for Automatic Classification of Sleep Disorders Based on Single-Lead Electrocardiogram
Authors: Urtnasan E, Joo EY, Lee KH.
Citation: Diagnostics (Basel). 2021 Nov 5;11(11):2054. doi: 10.3390/diagnostics11112054.
Study Population: 35 subjects with the control and the 4 sleep disorder groups (7 subjects of each group)
Task: Sleep apnea detection, insomnia (INS), periodic leg movement (PLM), REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD), and nocturnal frontal-lobe epilepsy (NFE)
Performance: F1 scores of 99.0%, 97.0%, 97.0%, 95.0%, and 98.0% for the CNT, INS, PLM, RBD, and NFE groups
Conclusion: We proposed an AI-enabled method for the automatic classification of sleep disorders based on a single-lead ECG signal. In addition, it represents the possibility of the sleep disorder classification using ECG only.

Title: Obstructive sleep apnea detection from single-lead electrocardiogram signals using one-dimensional squeeze-and-excitation residual group network
Authors: Yang Q, Zou L, Wei K, Liu G.
Citation: Comput Biol Med. 2021 Dec 6;140:105124. doi: 10.1016/j.compbiomed.2021.105124. Online ahead of print.
Data: Single-lead ECG (PhysioNet Apnea-ECG Database and UCD Database)
Performance: Accuracy of 90.3%, a sensitivity of 87.6%, and a specificity of 91.9% for per-segment detection
Conclusion: The proposed method can be integrated with wearable devices to realize inexpensive, convenient, and highly efficient OSA detectors.
